qas.question: What is the fourth and final stomach compartment in ruminants?
What is the abomasums close equivalent?
What does this site serve primarily as?

answers.text: a site for acid hydrolysis of microbial and dietary protein, preparing these protein sources for further digestion and absorption in the small intestine.

qas.question: What happens to digesta when it moves to the small intestine?

answers.text: the digestion and absorption of nutrients occurs

qas.question: What is also digested in the small intestine?

answers.text: Microbes produced in the reticulo-rumen are also digested in the small intestine

context: <a0_0>The abomasum<a0_0/> is the fourth and final stomach compartment in ruminants. It is a close equivalent of <a1_0>a monogastric stomach<a1_0/> (e.g., those in humans or pigs), and digesta is processed here in much the same way. It serves primarily as <a2_0>a site for acid hydrolysis of microbial and dietary protein, preparing these protein sources for further digestion and absorption in the small intestine.<a2_0/> Digesta is finally moved into the small intestine, where <a3_0>the digestion and absorption of nutrients occurs<a3_0/>. <a4_0>Microbes produced in the reticulo-rumen are also digested in the small intestine<a4_0/>.
